Award.AwardTitle: Developing New Methods for Obtaining Energy-based Acoustic Quantities

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although a microphone measures only pressure changes, multiple microphones can be used to extract significant information about acoustic energy flow, leading to more effective source and sound field characterization. This award will allow in-depth study of new methods for obtaining energy-based quantities from multi-microphone measurements, improving on traditional techniques that often require measurements be repeated with different microphone spacings. Initial development has already enhanced vector intensity measurements of rocket and military jet noise fields, but theoretical and experimental investigations will extend this work to other quantities in both enclosed and radiating sound fields as well as impactful applications. The effort will not only lead to improved and more efficient characterizations of sound sources and fields, but will be used to promote and further develop targeted activities to prepare a diverse, globally competitive workforce, support science education on all levels, and increase public awareness and appreciation of science through a broad outreach program.

To improve frequency bandwidth of energy-based acoustical measurements made with multi-microphone probes, new calculation methods based on taking gradients of the amplitude and phase variation across the microphones will be developed. Signal processing procedures for different acoustic quantities will be obtained from analytical investigations and laboratory experiments will be used to assess performance gains for different acoustical environments, probe configurations, and processing methods. This work has diverse practical applications in engineering acoustics, noise control, architectural acoustics, and source localization and tracking, a few of which will be investigated as a result of this award. Improved sound power measurement procedures will impact source noise assessment across a broad range of industries. New acoustical holography methodologies will result in more efficient three-dimensional sound source and field characterizations. Additionally, plane-wave tube measurement methods used to characterize absorption and sound transmission properties of different materials may benefit from the work. These new methods for obtaining energy-based acoustical quantities from multi-microphone measurements will guide development of probe microphone configurations optimized for the calculation procedures and prompt reviews of current national and international measurement standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy-based sound measurements provide richer information regarding sources, their radiated fields, and surrounding environments than ordinary pressure measurements.  While the benefits of energy-based measurements (like vector intensity) had been previously established for diverse applications in science and industry, making the required sound pressure measurements and estimating sound field gradients with sufficient accuracy had always been a limiting factor. The phase and amplitude gradient estimator (PAGE) method for obtaining energy-based acoustical measurements was developed at Brigham Young University in response to this challenge, and this research program allowed us to explore the theory, strengths, limitations, and applications of the PAGE method.

To extend our understanding of the PAGE method, we conducted analytical, numerical, and experimental investigations in both propagating and reverberant sound fields and developed PAGE methods for other energy-based quantities. One important contribution is a detailed error analysis of the PAGE and traditional calculation methods for different wave fields and in the presence of contaminating noise (always a factor in real measurements). As part of investigation, however, we discovered that deliberately-added noise placed in the vicinity of a tonal sound source can, in fact, improve PAGE-based source characterization over a broader range of frequencies.  We also showed that the PAGE method allowed us to physically separate the microphones in an energy-based sound probe beyond what is allowable by the traditional method, simultaneously improving the low and high-frequency measurement fidelity.  This and related research resulted in guidelines for improved probe designs.

In addition to hardware improvements for the PAGE method, our research yielded other new methods for processing signals from microphone arrays.  One of these was extending the PAGE method to noisy environments with relatively poor coherence between recordings.  This required developing a new phase unwrapping algorithm, and then reformulating the PAGE theory to account for the limited coherence. The phase unwrapping work ? which allows two microphones to be separated by more than the traditional half-wavelength limit ? led to a new way of doing beamforming referred to as the unwrapped phase interpolation (UPAINT) method.  The UPAINT method was successfully transferred to another project, where it was applied to better understand the turbulence noise sources in a jet engine plume.  We also used the phase gradient approach from the PAGE method to develop an alternative to acoustic beamforming; the phase-gradient pressure technique can resolve the direction of a source with high spatial resolution using relatively few microphones.  Although we uncovered PAGE method limitations, such as being unable to accurately obtain phase gradients in standing-wave or highly reverberant environments, PAGE and related techniques can be widely applied to improve sound source and field characterization.

This research program can broadly impact society through improved methods for characterizing sources, by application of these methods to other types of signals, through new collaborations and connections with industry and with international researchers, and through the advanced training of many students in a STEM field and through dissemination of results in the published literature. First, and perhaps most notably, this program showed we can improve the efficiency and efficacy of sound intensity-based sound power measurements.  Sound power is used to characterize the noise output from sources in many industries and focusing on its reduction benefits society through quieter products and living and working environments.  The PAGE intensity-based sound power method was shown to match an internationally-standardized reverberation chamber method much more closely than the traditional intensity method, for the same hardware.  Thus, the PAGE method can be incorporated into measurement standards as a new possibility for obtaining sound power estimates over broad frequency ranges.  Second, the underlying principles for PAGE could be applied to other types of signals, such as radio waves, or for acoustic signals in other frequency ranges. An interest in applying the PAGE method to the infrasound region for the purposes of monitoring and localizing very low-frequency noise sources has led to a direct collaboration with a leading international microphone manufacturer. Furthermore, presentation at industry-slanted conferences has led to conversations and connections with industry and with researchers in Japan and Spain. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, this program will benefit society through the training of 16 graduate and undergraduate students in physics and engineering, including several students from other universities and underrepresented groups. Combined, these students have published more than 25 theses, journal articles, and conference papers, with more forthcoming.  These students have also conducted STEM outreach programs and facility tours, helping them recognize their place as role models for the following generation of scientists and engineers.
